arm_group.description: Patients get no intervention at study start, but only at study end after seven months.
At the beginning and at the end of the study, this group receives a pharmacist's led medication review focusing on daily medicines use (= Polymedication Check).

If participants after recruitment violate inclusion criteria (e.g. change from autonomous medication management to external home care) or insists on intervention despite being randomised to control group or patient condition forces pharmacist to provide a PMC.

brief_summary.textblock:
Since October 2010, Swiss community pharmacies can offer a 'Polymedication Check' (PMC) to
      patients on ≥4 prescribed drugs taken over ≥3 months.

      Aims:

      To evaluate first experiences shortly after implementation, missed pharmaceutical care
      issues and barriers to implementation on pharmacist's level  as well as patient's
      acceptance through qualitative and descriptive studies To evaluate the impact of PMC in
      Swiss primary Care and to evaluate economic, clinical and humanistic outcomes in a
      subsequent randomized controlled trial.

clinical_study.brief_title: Polymedication Check - a Randomised Controlled Trial

detailed_description.textblock:
Evaluating the newly implemented Swiss 'Polymedication-Check', a specialised medication
      review and screening for adherence issues, offers a large field of interesting research
      questions. Using the current PMC-Protocol as a structured interview guide, pharmacists are
      able to document their counselling on medication use issues and other drug related problems.

      In a randomized-controlled trial we aim at analysing 800 recruited patients from 70 study
      pharmacies during seven months. Patients were recruited in the regions Basel,
      Aargau-Solothurn, Waadt in Switzerland and randomised using 1:1 block randomisation.

      Primary outcome focuses on the improvement of adherence and persistence after
      'Polymedication Check' (using medication possession ratio (MPR), gaps in medicines history
      records and patient's interviews).

      Second outcomes are time to planned or unplanned consulting with a physician or
      hospitalisation, knowledge, safety of medicines use and patients management of polypharmacy.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  more than 3 drugs over at least 3 months prior to recruitment

          -  german or french language (written and spoken)

          -  medicines use in self management

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  provision of Polymedication Check in the past

          -  living in a nursing home

          -  use of prefilled pill organiser or individually blistered medication

intervention.description:
Polymedication Check (PMC) is a pharmacist's led medication review focusing medicines management, adherence issues and other drug related problems.
The PMC has been implemented in 2010 as a new cognitive service provided by any community pharmacist to patient with polypharmacy (n>3 drugs) on long term conditions (> months). This specialised medication review follows a structured predefined protocol and is reimbursed by swiss health insurances.
As an outcome, pharmacist may install a compliance support e.g. weekly filled pill organizer.

facility.name: Pharmaceutical Care Research Group, University of Basel

clinical_study.official_title: Polymedication Check - Evaluation of the Impact of Community Pharmacy Based Medication Review on Medicines Use and Humanistic Outcomes

other_outcome.description: Compliance aids may be in use prior to recruitment, recommended after intervention by pharmacist, recommendation can be refused or accepted and the compliance aid can be filled by the patient himself or specialised service from the pharmacy.
other_outcome.time_frame: At study start and two weeks, four and seven months after after recruitment

overall_official.affiliation: Pharmaceutical Care Research Group, University of Basel
Pharmaceutical Care Research Group, University of Basel

primary_outcome.description: Improvement of adherence seven months after 'Polymedication-Check' using medication possession ratio (MPR), gaps and persistence out of history records from community pharmacy.
primary_outcome.measure: Medication possession ratio (MPR), gaps and persistence in medicines use

Clifford S, Barber N, Elliott R, Hartley E, Horne R. Patient-centred advice is effective in improving adherence to medicines. Pharm World Sci. 2006 Jun;28(3):165-70. Epub 2006 Sep 27.

Kwint HF, Faber A, Gussekloo J, Bouvy ML. Effects of medication review on drug-related problems in patients using automated drug-dispensing systems: a pragmatic randomized controlled study. Drugs Aging. 2011 Apr 1;28(4):305-14. doi: 10.2165/11586850-000000000-00000.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to planned or unplanned consulting with a physician or hospitalisation

secondary_outcome.description: Patient knowledge about his medicines use, assessed through PMC (intervention goup) and two telephone interviews (both groups)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: After two weeks, four and seven months after recruitment

secondary_outcome.description: Self report of adherence: is assessed with self administrated questionnaires and telephone interviews
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At study start and two weeks, four and seven months after after recruitment

secondary_outcome.description: Patients safety is assessed through a) telephone interview with a focus on perceived safety and b) number of drug related problems addressed and solved at study end.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: After two weeks, four and seven months after recruitment
